channel.title: Java - Defining Boundaries and Shapes
channel.description: So I was wondering if it was possible to define imaginary boundaries in a java program I'm working on without using any GUI what-so-ever. I plan on just printing out results to minimize the trouble i go through on this program. Shapes wise i still need them to be imaginary in a sense, but no use of GUI methods also.

item.title: Java - Defining Boundaries and Shapes
item.dc:creator: @RiiPiiNFtW RiiPiiNFtW
item.description:
@RiiPiiNFtW wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:16, topic:516889”]what that guy said ^^^^

http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/System.html#setOut(java.io.PrintStream)[/quote]Thanks, it helped. I got it working.

My new question is how exactly can you make scrollbar scroll through all characters in a JTextArea instead of assigning it to JScrollPane and making the actual JTextArea box scroll on a pane. :o

Fixed!

item.title: Java - Defining Boundaries and Shapes
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

[quote=“RiiPiiNFtW, post:14, topic:516889”][quote author=RiiPiiNFtW link=topic=635150.msg4285392#msg4285392 date=1366262251]
So i got some basic stuff done on my GUI, so now I have a few other questions.

1, Whats the class to add a like a graphing grid to the background of a Jpanel. No, not the GridLayout, but an actual grid.

2, How do I define a line segment onto a Jpanel? I have this, but I am not sure how to add it onto my Jpanel thats on my JFrame… :o

PS: Please excuse my nooby talk. im still learning GUI stuff with java as its a pain in the ass.

[code=java]package app;

import java.awt.BasicStroke;
import java.awt.Graphics;
import java.awt.Graphics2D;

import javax.swing.JPanel;

public class Line1 extends JPanel {

private static final long serialVersionUID = 1L;

public Line1(Graphics g) {
	paintComponent(g);
}

public void paintComponent(Graphics g) {
	super.paintComponent(g);

	Graphics2D g2d = (Graphics2D) g;

	float[] dash1 = { 2f, 0f, 2f };

	g2d.drawLine(20, 40, 250, 40);

	BasicStroke bs1 = new BasicStroke(1, BasicStroke.CAP_BUTT,
			BasicStroke.JOIN_ROUND, 1.0f, dash1, 2f);
	g2d.setStroke(bs1);
	g2d.drawLine(20, 80, 250, 80);

}

}
[/code]
[/quote]Heres a third question. I know its possible, but I was wondering if someone could point be towards the class that lets you put your output, like everything in a CMD prompt, into a Jpanel. :o[/quote]

you can redirect stdout

Read full topic

item.title: Java - Defining Boundaries and Shapes
item.dc:creator: @RiiPiiNFtW RiiPiiNFtW
item.description:
@RiiPiiNFtW wrote:

[quote=“RiiPiiNFtW, post:11, topic:516889”]So i got some basic stuff done on my GUI, so now I have a few other questions.

1, Whats the class to add a like a graphing grid to the background of a Jpanel. No, not the GridLayout, but an actual grid.

2, How do I define a line segment onto a Jpanel? I have this, but I am not sure how to add it onto my Jpanel thats on my JFrame… :o

PS: Please excuse my nooby talk. im still learning GUI stuff with java as its a pain in the ass.

[code=java]package app;

import java.awt.BasicStroke;
import java.awt.Graphics;
import java.awt.Graphics2D;

import javax.swing.JPanel;

public class Line1 extends JPanel {

private static final long serialVersionUID = 1L;

public Line1(Graphics g) {
	paintComponent(g);
}

public void paintComponent(Graphics g) {
	super.paintComponent(g);

	Graphics2D g2d = (Graphics2D) g;

	float[] dash1 = { 2f, 0f, 2f };

	g2d.drawLine(20, 40, 250, 40);

	BasicStroke bs1 = new BasicStroke(1, BasicStroke.CAP_BUTT,
			BasicStroke.JOIN_ROUND, 1.0f, dash1, 2f);
	g2d.setStroke(bs1);
	g2d.drawLine(20, 80, 250, 80);

}

}
[/code][/quote]Heres a third question. I know its possible, but I was wondering if someone could point be towards the class that lets you put your output, like everything in a CMD prompt, into a Jpanel. :o

item.title: Java - Defining Boundaries and Shapes
item.dc:creator: @RiiPiiNFtW RiiPiiNFtW
item.description:
@RiiPiiNFtW wrote:

So i got some basic stuff done on my GUI, so now I have a few other questions.

1, Whats the class to add a like a graphing grid to the background of a Jpanel. No, not the GridLayout, but an actual grid.

2, How do I define a line segment onto a Jpanel? I have this, but I am not sure how to add it onto my Jpanel thats on my JFrame… :o

PS: Please excuse my nooby talk. im still learning GUI stuff with java as its a pain in the ass.

[code=java]package app;

import java.awt.BasicStroke;
import java.awt.Graphics;
import java.awt.Graphics2D;

import javax.swing.JPanel;

public class Line1 extends JPanel {

private static final long serialVersionUID = 1L;

public Line1(Graphics g) {
	paintComponent(g);
}

public void paintComponent(Graphics g) {
	super.paintComponent(g);

	Graphics2D g2d = (Graphics2D) g;

	float[] dash1 = { 2f, 0f, 2f };

	g2d.drawLine(20, 40, 250, 40);

	BasicStroke bs1 = new BasicStroke(1, BasicStroke.CAP_BUTT,
			BasicStroke.JOIN_ROUND, 1.0f, dash1, 2f);
	g2d.setStroke(bs1);
	g2d.drawLine(20, 80, 250, 80);

}

}
[/code]

item.title: Java - Defining Boundaries and Shapes
item.dc:creator: @tigerclan tigerclan
item.description:
@tigerclan wrote:

[quote=“RiiPiiNFtW, post:8, topic:516889”][quote author=Whackatre link=topic=635150.msg4285198#msg4285198 date=1366244280]

[quote author=RiiPiiNFtW link=topic=635150.msg4285056#msg4285056 date=1366229191]

Your question is really unclear. If it’s really as simple as defining an imaginary box, just check if whatever point(s) you’re dealing with is within a specific region: x/y >= * && x/y < *.
[/quote]So basically i do need to use a GUI to render the objects as they freely move between defined boundaries?

i’m not sure what you are talking about. you can use logic to keep the objects on-screen (check if x < 0 or x > gui_width or y < 0 or y > gui_height, and if true, do something like reverse it) and optionally include an offset to deal with the size of the sprite. providing more relevant detail would be optimal.

also it seems like you do not really understand the difference between rendering and updating.
[/quote]I know about the GUI part which I assume is the rendering, but I want to know if its possible to use 2d shapes without a gui.[/quote]

This seems like an odd question… of course you can render 2d shapes without using a GUI. You do know what a GUI is, correct? 2d shapes wouldn’t be considered part of a GUI. GUIs are overlayed on top of the main graphics. Like all the interfaces in RS.

Read full topic

[/quote]So basically i do need to use a GUI to render the objects as they freely move between defined boundaries?

i’m not sure what you are talking about. you can use logic to keep the objects on-screen (check if x < 0 or x > gui_width or y < 0 or y > gui_height, and if true, do something like reverse it) and optionally include an offset to deal with the size of the sprite. providing more relevant detail would be optimal.

also it seems like you do not really understand the difference between rendering and updating.[/quote]I know about the GUI part which I assume is the rendering, but I want to know if its possible to use 2d shapes without a gui.

item.title: Java - Defining Boundaries and Shapes
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

Already been done for you: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/awt/Shape.html

All Known Implementing Classes: Arc2D, Arc2D.Double, Arc2D.Float, Area, BasicTextUI.BasicCaret, CubicCurve2D, CubicCurve2D.Double, CubicCurve2D.Float, DefaultCaret, Ellipse2D, Ellipse2D.Double, Ellipse2D.Float, GeneralPath, Line2D, Line2D.Double, Line2D.Float, Path2D, Path2D.Double, Path2D.Float, Polygon, QuadCurve2D, QuadCurve2D.Double, QuadCurve2D.Float, Rectangle, Rectangle2D, Rectangle2D.Double, Rectangle2D.Float, RectangularShape, RoundRectangle2D, RoundRectangle2D.Double, RoundRectangle2D.Float

Have fun

Read full topic
